text: I wanted to talk this evening about a few topics. One is the sort of overall course of where this practice takes us. What is this path all about? One of the things that people sometimes have difficulty with in practicing things like Vipassana meditation is that they don't understand the relationship between what we might call generic insights and the specific issues of their life. In other words, sometimes after a retreat a person will come up to me and they'll say, well, that was all great, but what do I do about the fact that my husband is bugging me? Or what do I do about my overeating? Or what do I do about the fact that I have this health condition? In other words, they haven't seen that the skills that we develop in this practice are generic skills that are applicable to each specific circumstance of life. So this is a theme I'd like you to keep in mind. Whatever issue may come up for you in your life, try to see how ultimately it goes back to the issues of learning how to experience states of mind and body in a skillful way. If you can remember that, then there'll be a very, very strong motivation to persevere with this practice. Over the months and years as one perseveres with the practice, one passes through various experiences. But from beginning to end, the only thing that you have to keep in mind is four things. I call them axioms. An axiom is a basic principle, an assumption in a philosophical system. And this vipassana practice has four axioms, and four is sort of a good number. If you know anything about mathematics, some of you may know group theory is based on four axioms. So four is a good number of axioms. It's not too few. If you have too few, your system is a little too general. If you have too many, your system is a little too closed or specific. But if you have a sort of medium-sized set of basic principles, that will often give you both generality and power. So I'd like you to keep four principles in mind as far as this practice goes. Two of them you already know, that you try to cultivate and deepen and abide in a skill of being attentive. That means being precise instead of nebulous. It means being able to bring continuity of awareness instead of having gaps in awareness. It means to be able to detect richness in whatever aspect of experience you are focusing on. It means to have detail in awareness. All of these are aspects of attentiveness or mindfulness. And one of the basic principles, axioms, is we try to be mindful, attentive. To what? To whatever is relevant in the moment. If you're washing dishes, you try to be completely attentive to the act of washing dishes. If you're making love, you try to be completely present in the act of making love. If you stub your toe, you try to be completely present in the sensations of stubbing the toe. Be mindful of all those aspects. If you get your ego stubbed, you understand what I mean? This happens from time to time. It's equivalent to stubbing your toe, except it's a little more gripping. You know, you fart in church or something like that. The self arises. You try to be as attentive as possible. The second axiom, there's a Japanese proverb, hyakunichi no seppo heishitotsu. It means you can give the greatest sermons for 100 days, but all you've got to do is fart once. People will remember the fart. They'll forget the sermons. So anyway, that's why it's a hard job being a meditative spiritual teacher. One of the axioms is you try to be as attentive as possible. Or you try to be attentive. The second axiom is that thing that I called equanimity. Try to be accepting. Accepting of your station in life? Not necessarily. But accepting of the way it makes you feel? Yeah. Yeah, be accepting of feeling. Don't fight with feeling, because when we fight with feeling, we're fighting with ourselves. The other two axioms or principles I call relativity and consistency. By relativity I mean we can't be absolutely attentive, and we can't be absolutely allowing or have absolute equanimity. We can only make a relative attempt to do so, and that's enough. The reason I put this principle in there is because we tend to be very judgmental of ourselves. I don't have enough equanimity. I don't have enough concentration. Do I have enough concentration? This kind of thing. Of course you don't have enough concentration. Of course you're not concentrating enough. Of course you don't have enough equanimity, and neither do I. We can't do these practices in a perfect way, but we can make an attempt to be a little more mindful than we would be otherwise, have a little more equanimity than we would otherwise. Fortunately, that's sufficient, because suffering is unnatural, and liberation is like a coiled spring. It's just waiting to happen. All we have to do is make the teeny movement that lets that spring free. So with a rather small amount of mindfulness and small amount of equanimity, you can initiate a natural process of release. So when you find yourself worrying and judging, you know, am I concentrating hard enough, and why can't I do this better? Go back to that principle of relativity and just ask yourself, am I trying? Am I making some effort? Am I more attentive than I would be otherwise? Am I more accepting than I would be otherwise? That's good. The third principle, a fourth principle or axiom is consistency. That means no matter what comes up, consistently attempt to observe it with mindfulness and equanimity. What do I mean by what comes up? Well, you could, as the result of this practice, you could have very pleasant experiences. It could happen that you, it would be like nectar flowing through your body or bliss or bright, clear light. Or you could encounter the realm of archetypes. You could literally talk to gods and goddesses, just like you could talk to a human being. I mean literally. See them, touch them, smell them. They're just as real as anything could be. That could happen to you somewhere along the line in your process of meditation. If you have startling experiences, unusual experiences, interesting experiences, blissful experiences, just observe. Observe them the same way you would observe the banal and ordinary experiences of itches and pressures, the same way you'd observe the breath. If the realms of the gods and goddesses open up to you, literally, and you can simply observe if the realms of the demons and monsters open up to you and you see them, and yet you simply observe them with equanimity and you're aware, changing, changing. OK, now this demon, now that demon, now that foxy goddess, now this foxy goddess. OK? You're laughing but it could happen to you somewhere along the line. And I'm not talking about hallucinations. Well, I am, I mean, but I'm talking about hallucinations that are as vivid as so-called reality. So then what's reality? To be able to just continue to observe with consistency, you equanimously observe whatever phenomena. Your whole body may fill with bliss and light upon occasion. And just be aware, a little more bliss on the right side, a little less bliss on the left, OK? Changing this way, changing that way, just like you'd be aware of the breath. Then the purification will continue. You may also get some unusually unpleasant experiences. I already described these icky sticky feelings, these vulnerable feelings, feelings like you don't have any skin left on your body, feelings like bugs are crawling through your veins. You just want to jump out of your skin, your body shakes, you go through all sorts of weird movements and sounds. If those kinds of unpleasant experiences happen to you, simply consistently observe them with precision and allowing. And then the process of purification will continue. If somewhere along the line an experience is very pleasant or very unpleasant or very startling or very boring and you forget to observe with mindfulness and equanimity, then the process of purification stops for a while. So no matter what comes up, if fear comes up, it's entirely possible that as you go into deeper states and you begin to approach real liberation experiences, as you come right to the door of liberation, you'll encounter the fence that separates the personal from the transpersonal, that separates the vulnerable from the invulnerable. And that fence has a name. It's called fear. Not fear of this or that, just the generic phenomenon, fear per se. And if you continue to observe the mind-body state of that fear, then you'll be able to bore through that fence and go over to the other side. But it won't be fear for any reason. It will just be fear. It will just be there for no reason whatsoever. You could be in the safest possible environment and have profound feelings of fear because you're close to an experience of going beyond the limited identity. So all along the path, from beginning to end, all a person does is apply these four principles. If you remember them, you'll always have the answer for what to do, at least insofar as vipassana goes. Now of course, are there other ways to become fully enlightened outside of vipassana? Absolutely. Is vipassana the best way? Not necessarily. Does it work? Yeah, it does work. That we can say. It certainly is a way. So everything that I present to you, of course, is within the structure of the vipassana way of working. When you work in other systems, these principles may or may not be applicable. Each system of liberation is self-contained. It's self-consistent. It has all the necessary and sufficient elements for doing the job, so to speak. So when I give these talks, please understand, everything we do here is within the context of vipassana. There are two other major Buddhist practices, Zen and Vajrayana, and outside of Buddhism, there are many practices that bring liberation. So these talks are just about one particular approach to the issue. And in this approach, from beginning to end, whatever comes up in your experience, you're mindful, you're equanimous, you understand that you don't expect to be able to do it perfectly, you just do your best in a relative way, and you keep on doing it no matter what. No matter what reactions take place to having done it. So as the result of something as seemingly innocuous as remaining alert, who could object? What's the remaining alert? Plugging the gaps in awareness. It seems to be innocuous, but it's not innocuous. It can initiate incredibly blissful experiences and incredibly uncomfortable experiences in the process of purification. So you consistently observe those experiences. If you remember these principles, then what will happen is, as the months and years pass, your understanding will deepen, understanding about fundamental issues, and the blockages to happiness will break up of their own, just naturally. At first slowly, but then as time goes on, it will accelerate dramatically. So in your tenth year of meditation, you grow as much in a week as you grew in your whole first year of meditation. And in your twentieth year of meditation, you feel every day you're literally a new self. It's like you're literally born. You get to live as many lives as there are days in the year. You're just born in the world anew every morning. Every day is very, very big. So this is sort of the long sweep of the practice. As the process of purification or catharsis is going on, your subjective experiences as you sit and meditate are going to vary. Sometimes it's going to be very easy to meditate. You'll sit down, the mind will be concentrated, the body will be full of pleasant vibrations, and it seems like you could sit there forever. Other times when you sit down, you'll have the opposite experience. The mind will be very scattered and the body will feel very antsy and it's like torture to sit there for even five minutes. What's important to remember is as long as you're applying those four principles, you're moving forward insofar as, and you cannot move backwards, insofar as the ultimate goal of this practice. However, since the blockages are sort of like fossils and they exist at deeper and deeper geological strata within consciousness, depending on the rhythm of release of these blockages, by blockages I mean basically the holding patterns from our past experience, what we call in Buddhism, sankharas. Something like, I guess, what they would call complexes or knots in psychotherapy. According to the rhythm of the release of these blockages, your subjective experience will sometimes be hard, sometimes be easy. But the release is always taking place as long as you consistently, as best you can, try to be mindful and allowing. There will be a tendency, however, when a layer of blockage has come to the surface and been evaporated through the clear light of observation and you feel good subjectively. There's a tendency to feel at that time, oh, I'm making progress. This practice is for me. This is great. And that will go on for a certain period of time until the next deeper level of blockage shakes loose and starts to percolate up to the surface. At that time, as I say, the mind will scatter and the body will feel yucky and there'll be a tendency to think, what am I doing wrong? I felt so great before. Last month I felt so great and I could concentrate. Now it's like I never meditated before. Why am I going backwards? What have I done wrong? But you haven't gone backwards. Deeper material has percolated upwards and will continue to percolate upwards for many, many years and indeed decades. So as far as the subjective experience goes, it's going to be hard, it's going to be easy, it's going to be hard, it's going to be easy, it's going to be hard, it's going to be easy. What you learn after a few years is not to evaluate your practice in terms of whether you feel like sitting or don't feel like sitting or whether you have pleasant experiences as you sit or whether it's a struggle to sit. You learn not to evaluate the practice that way. Then how to evaluate the practice? The second best way to evaluate the practice is to observe the spontaneous, permanent improvements in your relationships with human beings. Just the effects in ordinary life. That's the second best way. You'll notice that even when your subjective experiences on the cushion may not be all that pleasant, the changes are still taking place in daily life. The very best way to evaluate your practice, however, is to not evaluate it at all. To simply do it. The same way you simply breathe. It's just part of life. So over the course of the months and years of your life, if you do a little bit of sitting each day and do something like this with regularity several times a year, you will work through layer after layer of blockage. And your understandings about the really important fundamental issues will deepen and deepen. The insight is a many-faceted jewel. And different teachers emphasize different facets, different sides of that jewel. So sometimes people get very confused. They don't realize it's one jewel, one wisdom. Early Buddhism put a great emphasis on that aspect of insight called knowing how not to suffer. Is it important? What do you think? Just wait till the next time you suffer in some teeny little way. It won't even have to be major. Just some little thing, some little frustration. You'll see how important it is. But that's not the only facet to insight. There's a whole other aspect which was not talked about much in early Buddhism, but is very much emphasized in Zen Buddhism, which is this whole aspect of experiencing oneness with things, merging, being able to extend your identity to include the objects that you look at, the people that you interact with, etc. Another aspect of insight or spiritual wisdom that's very much emphasized in the third tradition of Buddhism, the Vajrayana, is the understanding of how the flow of consciousness creates appearances. Actually, how it is, the process by which the vibration of consciousness forms things. And in the Vajrayana tradition, they call it visualization, but it's much, much more than that. What you actually do is learn how to participate in the activity of consciousness that manifests things. You understand how it is that appearances well up out of nothing. This, of course, seems very irrelevant to people when they begin their practice, but this is sort of like post-graduate stuff. When you begin your practice, you're very much concerned with the ABCs, which is natural. Just the basics, how can I get a little more concentration, how can I get a little more patience, a little peace of mind. But after many, many years of meditation, you become interested in other kinds of topics that become utterly fascinating. The sequence of events that are happening every millisecond, every microsecond, that lead from the void to appearances. The appearance of the room, the appearance of the people. I know we tend to think there is a thing called a room here. There are things called people here. But there's a whole other way of experiencing that. Eventually, one gets insight and one actually sees, moment by moment, how it is that nothing is able to create something. It's what in the Jewish mystical tradition is called Briha Yesh Ma'en in Hebrew, the continuous creation of something from nothing, which is taken as the highest realization in the Jewish mystical tradition. In other words, somebody once asked Einstein, if he could have his druthers, if he could have exactly what he wanted, what would he want? He said, I'm paraphrasing, but in essence, if I could know, if I was given any knowledge that I could have any knowledge, what I would really like to know and what I've sought all these decades in my science is I want to know how God creates the world. What's God's process in creating the world? I'm paraphrasing, but in essence, that's what he said. In saying that, whether he was aware of it or not, and I'm not sure he was even consciously aware of it, of course, he was drawing directly on his Jewish spiritual roots. Because the Jewish mystical tradition is not so interested in union with God. Jewish mystical tradition is interested in actually figuring out how God works. Sort of figures, right? Interestingly enough, so is the Buddhist tradition, although they don't use the word God. We don't use the word God, but we do use the word, the source. The source in the Buddhist tradition is described exactly the same way that the source in the Jewish tradition is described. And there has been, as far as I know, no contact until very recently between these traditions. So when Isaac Luria in Palestine in the 16th century described expansion and contraction and continuous creation, there is no reason to think that he had any contact with Buddhist meditators or people like that who describe the activity of impermanence as expanding, contracting, and molding our experience moment by moment. So you pass through a sequence of insights and it culminates in an actual moment by moment perception of how God works, to use a very un-Buddhist phrase. Then you're never bored anymore. That I can promise you. You may have heard of Bodhidharma, that according to legend he sat looking at a wall for nine years. How can anybody look at a wall for nine years? Well, he wasn't looking at an object called the wall, assuming this legend is true. He was looking at the source creating that wall moment by moment, moment by moment. And a person would no longer get bored looking at the wall than God gets bored creating it, if you were able to perceive that. So you pass through a sequence of insights, starting with things that anybody can understand, like how to experience pain without suffering, and culminating in things that maybe sound pretty weird to people, like how does the self and the world arise out of nothingness every moment? And where does that culminate in? What's the purpose of all of that? Is that the end of the path? You become a liberated person, you're never bored anymore, you can dance with the source, you don't have to worry so much about suffering. Is that the end of the path? Actually, no. Just as concentration is the primary tool that allows a person to attain these insights and purifications, these insights and purifications are the tool that allows a person to do something else. And that something else is to function as an effortless source of benefit to the people around you. The important term here is effortless. If we try to be good and loving people, to be richly warm and human people, without having gone through the process of insight and purification, then it's like trying to put a beautiful paint job over the old paint without having cleaned off the old paint first. It won't take. It may look okay, but sooner or later the crud starts to ooze up through the appearance of the loving, compassionate human being. Anybody here speak Japanese? Jigane ga deru, they say in Japanese. It means, when you, the underlying material seeps through the paint. There's no exact English translation. So the trick is that the process of insight and purification naturally leads to the life of a kind of effortless service and loving kindness and compassion. And that's the ultimate goal of this practice. We can look upon how this naturally happens from two perspectives. One, remember I said insight is a many faceted jewel and one side of it, one facet, is a knowledge of oneness. So you begin to look upon your world as yourself, quite tangibly, quite literally. And you experience the people that come in front of you as actually being you, in some very real sense. So it's only natural that the continuity, if you are to continue your practice, if you start out with your practice and the goal is liberation for yourself and as the result of continuing that practice, the definition of yourself now changes to encompass the world, then if you wish to continue with liberating yourself, you have to make some contribution to liberating the world. What form will that contribution take? Many, many possible forms. Many possible forms, depending on what? Depending on the culture you live in, depending on your preconceptions, depending on your personality, depending on your ability, depending on your interests and proclivities. But in some way there will be a reaching out. It can range from social activism to being a meditation teacher to being a wizard, cultivating the special powers of the mind, psychic powers, to living an ordinary life but subtly pervading each person you meet with a quality of loving kindness that they may not even be aware of. So some of the ways that we benefit or help the world around us as an extension of our own liberation are sort of on the surface and obvious. You build a hospital or you work to change society or save the environment in some way. But some of the ways that we work are subtle. The nice thing about the subtle ways is we can always do them. We may or may not be able to be successful with changing things in the grosser material world. But we can always, literally all our waking hours, be pervading our environment with subtle positive influences. There are several ways that this can be done. I'll describe them to you. One is a practice that we call metta or loving kindness. A second one is a practice called karana or compassion. I said that there were two ways we could benefit. One is by, or two ways that the practice naturally leads from liberation to benefiting. One is by that realization of oneness. The other is going to be perhaps a little bit hard for you to understand at this time, but it will become very evident as the months and years of your practice goes on. The result of the vipassana practice is that you realize that all experience is made up of atomic vibrations. Once you realize that, you can, this is a little hard to describe to people, you might say that your experience becomes clarified, it becomes transparent. Yes, that's one way to look at it. You come to realize that the actual substance of experience, hearing, seeing, smelling, tasting, the feeling body and the thinking mind, the actual substance of experience becomes transparent and elastic. Most people, their experience is very opaque. Doesn't it seem opaque? The walls seem very solid, very opaque. You don't feel like you can look through them. The self seems very opaque, the body is very opaque, and it doesn't seem elastic and vibratory. This room does not seem, for most people, elastic and vibratory. But as you go through the process of insight and purification, your experience becomes clear and elastic. So it can resonate like a bell. That's the elasticity. And it can take on any color you want. When something is transparent, you can easily color it any way you want. So, in the practice of the loving kindness and compassion, we first experience the mind-body process as being transparent and elastic. And then we started vibrating with a vibration of compassion and loving kindness. And we color it with a little drop of coloration of compassion and loving kindness. And because it's elastic, all we have to do is put that little vibration on, and it just continues to vibrate effortlessly all day, loving kindness. And because our experience has become literally clarified, all we have to do is put one little drop of friendliness in it, and just like a drop of food coloring spreads in a tumbler of water, the whole mind-body process is just filled with boundless friendliness and compassion. So there's a natural link between the purification process and vipassana, which literally transforms the substance of our being so that it can effortlessly take on the vibration and color of being fully human in the best of what it means to be a human being. That's where this path culminates. That's what it's all about. So you might say that there are, actually, in traditional Buddhism, they had four things that they did. When they started people out, people didn't have any concentration, but at least they could give to support the monks. And it's still true today. If you go to Southeast Asia, people may not have the time to develop concentration power and things like that, but they'll always, everybody has the wherewithal to put one spoon of curry into the monk or nun's bowl. And that's called dana, or giving. If you can give, then you can also go beyond, that becomes a basis of making merit, and then you can go beyond just giving and you can develop concentration. So the purpose of giving is to put yourself in, set up a certain frame of mind so that you feel good about yourself, you've helped another, and now you can sit down and the mind is calm and you can become concentrated. The purpose of developing concentration, it's not an end to itself. It's a tool that will allow you to purify and gain insight and become free. But that's not an end to itself either. When you become free, the entire substance of your being has become transparent and elastic. Now you can be anything you want. And the thing that you want to be, of course, is a good human being. And so you learn how to literally resonate out into your world this friendliness and this compassion. Not that you necessarily go through life with a smile at every single thing, but the pores of your being are always smiling. And that subtle, those thousands of subtle smiles that come out of your skin, they have a cumulative influence on the people that you interact with. And that's how you give. You give yourself back to the world. So it sort of goes full circle. You begin with this practice of dhana, or giving, in a material sense. And then that leads to samadhi, or concentration. Samadhi leads to prajna, or wisdom. And prajna leads to another kind of dhana, another kind of giving. But in this case, it's a giving of your entire being. That is the broad sweep of what this path is about. Any questions? Question was asked, what is my definition of addiction? I use the three words addiction, compulsion, and drivenness as being synonymous. They're the same thing as far as I'm concerned. Is there a particular addiction or compulsion you're interested in? Yeah. I just use those words synonymously. The mechanism that I like to, the model I should say for addictive mechanism that I like to use is, well let's say a person has a substance abuse addiction. So they say I have a problem with alcohol. Okay, but let's look a little bit deeper at that. Do you really have a problem with the substance called alcohol? Or is the problem that when you don't have alcohol you feel uncomfortable and in order to cope with that discomfort you take the alcohol? Of course it's the latter. It has nothing to do with the substance. It's the fact that without the substance the person feels discomfort and they have no other coping mechanism for it other than to use the alcohol. But is the issue really the discomfort? I would say looked at a little deeper, the issue is that the person feels discomfort and doesn't have the tools to experience that discomfort without suffering. They don't know how to observe it. They don't know how to let it spread. They don't know how to be aware of its impermanence. So that ultimately the problem is an issue of not having skill at feeling. So on the surface it seems that they have a problem with a substance called alcohol. Looked at a little deeper we can say they have a problem with certain kinds of discomfort. But looked at deeper still, the issue is they don't have a skill at how to experience that discomfort without suffering. So it goes back to the work we do here on the cushion. Does that make sense? If a person has a compulsive disorder and works in our meditation program, we usually recommend that in addition to the practice of the meditation they get some sort of behaviorally oriented external support system. If not a 12-step program then some sort of counselor or something that is working at the level of behavior. If a person maintains their abstinence but does not develop the skill with the unpleasant sensations associated with the abstinence, they can go their whole life that way. They'll avoid the gross suffering caused by the addiction, but they'll never come to grips with the subtle suffering, I mean really come to grips with the subtle suffering that underlies that compulsion. So they don't have an effortless abstinence. But if a person is able to feel through, I like that phrase, you know, we usually think about I gotta talk it through, I gotta think it through, I gotta act it out. Well all of those have their place, but there's a whole other human endeavor. It's what you're learning here when you sit through those discomforts that you've been having. You're learning how to feel something through, deal with it feeling at the level of feeling. If the person learns how to feel through the sensations that were driving the behavior, then they'll have an effortless abstinence. They will become recovered alcoholics. That of course goes against what they tell you in the 12-step programs. In the 12-step programs they tell you you're always recovering, you're never recovered. And there's a good reason for that, because most people don't recover. And most people will fool themselves thinking they do recover. Recovered means that you have felt through all that poison and pain. And that's something that you could do without meditation, but it would be hard. It could happen without meditation, just naturally. But meditation will make it more likely to happen, especially Vipassana meditation. So there are two aspects to recovering. One is you have to abstain, otherwise the sensations won't come to the surface. The other though is if you want to really recover, you have to feel through those sensations until they're not in the way anymore. They don't drive and distort behavior anymore. Of course when you work through the driver sensations behind a major compulsion, you will have also worked through most of the driver sensations in your life. Your whole life will change. That's why Shelly's whole life changed over the years of working through her eating compulsion. Everything changed. So unless a person is abstinent, at least to a certain degree, they won't be able to get the feelings to the surface to work with. That's one reason why it's good to be in a behaviorally oriented therapy in addition to doing meditation. But there's another reason if you meditate why it's not always the case, but often, why we would suggest that they do do something like a 12-step. Can you guess what it is? Why we would want people to have some sort of behaviorally oriented controlling force on them if they were meditating on these feelings? Well, what's going to happen is before a bubble bursts, it has to reach optimal size. And when you work with the sensations, meditation represents the opposite coping mechanism of addiction. Pain comes up. The substance is a coping mechanism. It anesthetizes the pain, makes it go away. And you can cope, sort of. Of course, it brings much greater pain because of the force of the abuse of the substance in your life. But it does give you a kind of coping mechanism, a coping mechanism called go unconscious. Meditation offers an alternate coping mechanism, but unfortunately, it happens to be the exact opposite coping mechanism. Go conscious, fully conscious. Therefore, in switching from the old coping mechanism to the new coping mechanism, one is bound to pass through an awkward intermediate zone where the old coping mechanism is being let go of, but the new coping mechanism is not in place anymore, or in place yet, I should say. At that time, there's going to be a very strong tendency to act out those feelings. And unless there's a behaviorally oriented program, you might find as the result of the meditation that the compulsions get worse for a little while before they break up. Because the sensations are now being allowed to come to the surface. They're not being stuffed down. And it's those sensations that you've been drinking over, or eating over, or smoking over, or beating your wife over, or gambling over. So that's another reason why, in my experience, it does best to combine behaviorally oriented therapies with the meditation if you have a real compulsive disorder. Not if you're just driven, you know, the usual neurotic kinds of things that we all have. You don't have to go into a 12-step program. But if it's a disorder, if it's the center of your life, you know if you have a compulsive disorder. I mean, it's very evident. I usually recommend the double approach. The surface approach of controlling the behavior through therapy and the really deep approach of the meditation to bring the sensations to the surface.
